title: Renormalization of CP-violating nuclear forces
speaker: 罗青杨
paperAbstract:
Electric dipole moments of nuclei, diamagnetic atoms, and certain molecules are induced by -violating nuclear forces. Naive dimensional analysis predicts these forces to be dominated by long-range one-pion-exchange processes with short-range forces entering only at next-to-next-to-leading order in the chiral expansion. Based on renormalization arguments we argue that a consistent picture of -violating nuclear forces requires a leading-order short-distance operator contributing to  
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline-block"><msup><mi></mi><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><msub><mi>S</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>−</mo><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>
  transitions due to the attractive and singular nature of the strong tensor force in the  
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline-block"><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>
  channel. The short-distance operator leads to 𝑂⁡(1) corrections to static and oscillating, relevant for axion searches, electric dipole moments. We discuss strategies how the finite part of the associated low-energy constant can be determined in the case of 𝐶⁢𝑃 violation from the QCD 
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline-block"><mrow><mover><mi>θ</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover></mrow></math>
 term by the connection to charge-symmetry violation in nuclear systems.
